Yes, here are some examples of longitudinal studies that have followed parent involvement through a child's education and into adulthood:

1) The National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health (Add Health) - This study followed a nationally representative sample of American adolescents in grades 7-12 in 1994-1995 and tracked them into young adulthood. Findings showed that parental involvement was positively related to academic achievement, college attendance, and higher socioeconomic status in young adulthood.

2) The National Child Development Study (NCDS) - This study began in 1958 and has followed a cohort of British children from birth to adulthood. One finding showed that parental involvement in education (e.g., attending parent-teacher conferences) was positively associated with higher educational attainment and earnings in adulthood.

3) The Early Steps Multisite Study - This study followed low-income children and families from preschool through the end of sixth grade. Parental involvement in the preschool years was found to lead to higher levels of achievement in math and reading in fifth grade, as well as higher levels of positive behavior and social skills.

Overall, these longitudinal studies provide compelling evidence for the importance of parent involvement in education and its potential long-term benefits for children's academic and career success.
